review.title: The empirical Christoffel function in Statistics and Machine Learning
review.abstract: We illustrate the potential in statistics and machine learning of the Christoffel function, or more precisely, its empirical counterpart associated with a counting measure uniformly supported on a finite set of points. Firstly, we provide a thresholding scheme which allows to approximate the support of a measure from a finite subset of its moments with strong asymptotic guaranties. Secondly, we provide a consistency result which relates the empirical Christoffel function and its population counterpart in the limit of large samples. Finally, we illustrate the relevance of our results on simulated and real world datasets for several applications in statistics and machine learning: (a) density and support estimation from finite samples, (b) outlier and novelty detection and (c) affine matching.

sections.heading: 3.2 When µ is the Lebesgue measure
sections.text: In this section we will consider the important case of the Lebesgue measurement on a compact set S-Rp such that cl (int (S) = S. It is known that in this case the Christoffel function contains information about the set S; see, for example, the discussion in Section 3.1. In particular, the scaled Christoffel function remains positively on the inside of S. We push this idea further and present a new result stating that it is possible to regenerate the set S with strong asymptotic guarantees by carefuly swelling the corresponding scaled Christoffel function.

sections.heading: 4.1 Rationale
sections.text: In this section, we will describe some applications for which the properties of the Christoffel function prove to be very useful in a statistical context. We will consider only the case of limited support. A relevant property of the Christoffel scaled function is that it encodes information about the support and density of a population measure µ: • Ma'te ́ et al. (1991), Totik (2000) and Kroo and Lubinsky (2012) provide asymptotic results that include the density of the input measure. • Theorem 3.8 provides asymptotic results in connection with the support of input measurement. The support and density of a measure is of interest for many statistical applications. However, the above results are limited to population scales that are not accessible in a statistical context. In the context of empirical Christoffel functions, Theorem 3.11 suggests that these properties are still valid (at least in the limit of large samples) when using the empirical measurement of population size.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we examined the potential of the Christoffel empirical function for some applications in statistics and machine learning, and this question led us to examine its theoretical properties as well as possible paths towards application, largely within a statistical framework. On the theoretical side, we have proposed two main contributions: the first provides an explicit threshold scheme that enables us to regain support for a measure with strong asymptotic guarantees. Although this property is rooted in the long history of results in terms of asymptotic properties of Christoffel function, we have created a systematic way to adjust the threshold and degree of convergence guarantees; the second main contribution relates the Christoffel empirical function to its population counterpart. This type of results is new and paves the way to a much more precise understanding of the relationships between these two objects in a small sample environment. On the practical side, we have presented the relevance of the Christoffel function as a practical tool in a particular context.

metadata.abstractText: We illustrate the potential in statistics and machine learning of the Christoffel function, or more precisely, its empirical counterpart associated with a counting measure uniformly supported on a finite set of points. Firstly, we provide a thresholding scheme which allows to approximate the support of a measure from a finite subset of its moments with strong asymptotic guaranties. Secondly, we provide a consistency result which relates the empirical Christoffel function and its population counterpart in the limit of large samples. Finally, we illustrate the relevance of our results on simulated and real world datasets for several applications in statistics and machine learning: (a) density and support estimation from finite samples, (b) outlier and novelty detection and (c) affine matching.
